subject: Re: [junit] Providing test data
msgSnippet: Create a directory tree. Jar it. Place the jar in your distribution jar. Use getResource to get a handle to the jar. UnJar it to a temporary location. Destroy
messageBody:
Create a directory tree. Jar it. Place the jar in your distribution jar.
Use getResource to get a handle to the jar. UnJar it to a temporary
location. Destroy the directory tree in your tearDown().

On Thu, 10 Jan 2002, Ives Aerts wrote:

> I've recently started to use JUnit on an embedded project and I ran
> into a problem with test data.
>
> Our product has a small internal filesystem on flash ram. So far, the
> most convenient way to include test data with JUnit tests was to add
> them to the test jar file and use java.lang.Class.getResource().
>
> The problem now is that we need to test a set of classes that operate
> on directory trees instead of files. So we need the likes of
> java.io.File.getParent() and java.io.File.list(). AFAIK, that doesn't
> work with the advised approach of using getResource().
>
> Any suggestions on how to handle this?
>
> Cheers,
> -Ives
> ______________________________________________________________________
> Ives Aerts (senior R&D engineer) Sony Visual Products Europe
> Ives.Aerts@... http://www.nee-b.sonycom.com
> `Blimey, this redistribution of wealth is trickier than I thought.'
> (Dennis Moore - Monty Python's flying circus, episode 37)
